Weighted inductive limits of spaces of holomorphic functions arise in fields like linear partial differential equations and convolution equations, Fourier analysis, distribution theory, complex analysis and spectral theory. The interest in a systematic investigation of such inductive limits in both the continuous and the holomorphic case derives from several applications, but also from an effort to understand the (intricate) structure of the corresponding spaces; it dates back (at least) to the joint articles [9] and [lo] of the first-named author with R. MEISE and with R. MEISE, W. H. SUMMERS, respectively. A new, important approach to the study of weighted inductive limits was developed in [lo]; viz., the method of "projective descriptions": It is a well-known fact that, in general, an inductive limit topology is not directly accessible from its definition and that, in particular, there is no "good", useful and sufficiently explicit "formula" for its continuous seminorms which would allow direct computations and estimates as they are required in the applications. Here we include such extensions and, to some extent, use VOGT'S methods, results (in particular, Lemma 2.3 is taken from his work) and, above all, his conditions (wQ) and (Q). The present study is also intended to provide better insight into the structure of (LF)-spaces, and it is relevant in connection with some questions in the abstract theory of such spaces: It is an open problem (due to GROTHENDIECK) whether regular (LF)-spaces must be complete, and it is also not known if sequentially retractive (LF)-spaces are always acyclic. In our context here, however, both questions have affirmative answers.
